questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of fever, severe earache, vomiting, and reduced hearing. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, red tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks, and a yellow spot is visible. What stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) is this child most likely in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

 

Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) evolves in five classic stages:

 

1. Stage of Tubal Occlusion:

 

  • Cause: Eustachian tube blockage due to URTI
  • TM: Retraction, horizontal malleus handle, dull cone of light
  • Symptoms: Mild earache, conductive hearing loss
  • No fever, usually no visible fluid

 

2. Stage of Presuppuration:

 

  • TM: Red, congested, "cart-wheel" appearance
  • Symptoms: Marked earache, fever, restlessness, tinnitus
  • Exudate begins to form in middle ear

 

3. Stage of Suppuration (Answer):

 

  • TM: Bulging, red, yellow spot (site of imminent rupture), loss of landmarks
  • Symptoms: Severe earache, high fever (102–103°F), vomiting, possibly convulsions
  • Pus starts to collect in middle ear & mastoid

 

4. Stage of Resolution:

 

  • TM ruptures → pus drains
  • Relief of pain, fever subsides
  • Perforation often in anteroinferior quadrant, discharge becomes mucopurulent

 

5. Stage of Complication:

 

  • If untreated or virulent organism:
    • Mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, facial palsy, meningitis, brain abscess, etc.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage of tubal occlusion: Only mild retraction and deafness, not fever or bulging TM

 

Option B. Stage of presuppuration: TM is red but not bulging; no yellow spot

 

Option D. Stage of resolution: TM has ruptured, symptoms start improving

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suppurative stage of ASOM is marked by bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever, indicating accumulation of pus in the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 62

choices.text: Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture
The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs
Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal
Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the physiological basis for body equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

 

  • The body maintains equilibrium using a push-pull mechanism between bilateral vestibular systems. If one side becomes hyperactive or hypoactive, balance is disturbed. Reflexes like the:
    • Vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) stabilize gaze
    • Vestibulocervical reflex controls head position
    • Vestibulospinal reflex maintains trunk and limb posture
      Together, they ensure dynamic correction of posture and gaze.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture: Incorrect. Balance is a multisensory function, involving vestibular, visual, and somatosensory systems. Relying on vision alone is insufficient and does not explain conditions like vestibular ataxia.

 

Option B. The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs: Incorrect. The vestibular system integrates input from visual and somatosensory systems, especially during head movement or positional changes. It does not act in isolation.

 

Option D. Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance: Incorrect. A static imbalance due to vestibular dysfunction (e.g. unilateral vestibulopathy) can cause vertigo and ataxia even at rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Equilibrium is maintained by a bilateral vestibular push-pull system integrated with visual and somatosensory input, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal responses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 18

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden decrease in vision in right eye. While assessing his pupils, when light was shone in the left eye, both pupils constricted and when light was shone in the right eye, both pupils dilated. The likely abnormality is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marcus Gunn pupil

 

Option C:

 

  • This is a form of paradoxical response of a pupil to light.

  • Marcus Gunn pupil is characterized by a relative afferent pupillary defect.

  • Causes: Retinal disease, Optic nerve disease, Glaucoma, Trauma.

  • It is detected via SWINGING FLASHLIGHT TEST.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s Pupil: if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.

 

Option B. Horner’s Pupil: This is a part of Horner's syndrome, which includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the affected side. The pupil in Horner's syndrome is smaller on the affected side but reacts normally to light and accommodation. This is not consistent with the described findings.

 

Option D. Adie’s Pupil: This involves a tonic pupil that is larger than the other and reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. It's usually caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye. This does not match the clinical picture of an RAPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with a sudden decrease in vision in one eye and an observed pupil response where shining light in the unaffected eye causes both pupils to constrict, but shining it in the affected eye causes both to dilate, the likely diagnosis is a Marcus Gunn pupil (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), indicative of asymmetric optic nerve dysfunction.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 312

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a one-week history of itching and fullness in her right ear. She reports no pain but mentions a slight hearing reduction. She has a history of swimming regularly. On examination, the external auditory canal is erythematous and has black-headed filamentous debris. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Which microorganism is most commonly responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus Niger

 

The clinical presentation suggests otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal. Aspergillus niger is the most common cause of otomycosis, particularly in individuals with frequent water exposure (swimming).

 

 

  • Key features of otomycosis:

    • Itching (most common symptom).

    • Ear fullness or blocked sensation.

    • Mild hearing loss (due to fungal debris).

    • Black-headed filamentous fungal debris (suggestive of Aspergillus niger infection).

    • Minimal pain and no significant purulent discharge (unlike bacterial otitis externa).

  • Risk factors:

    • Frequent swimming (creates a moist environment).

    • Use of topical antibiotics or steroids (alters ear flora).

    • Immunocompromised states (e.g., diabetes, HIV).

  • Management:

    • Aural toilet (removal of fungal debris).

    • Topical antifungal therapy (clotrimazole, ketoconazole, or nystatin ear drops).

    • Avoidance of moisture in the external auditory canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa:

  • Incorrect, because Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes Malignant otitis externa, not otomycosis.

  • Bacterial otitis externa presents with more pain and purulent discharge, not black fungal debris.

 

Option C. Candida Albicans:

  • Incorrect, because Candida albicans can cause otomycosis but is less common than Aspergillus species.

  • Candida infections usually appear as white, curd-like debris rather than black-headed fungal growth.

  • More common in immunocompromised patients or those with chronic antibiotic use.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus Aureus:

  • Incorrect, because Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterial pathogen and does not cause otomycosis.

  • It is more commonly associated with localized infections like furuncles or bacterial otitis externa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus niger is the most common cause of otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal. It presents with itching, ear fullness, and black-headed filamentous fungal debris, particularly in individuals with frequent swimming exposure. Management includes aural toilet and topical antifungal therapy.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: Identify the Field Defect.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bjerrum Scotoma

 

Option A: 

 

Bjerrum scotoma is a localized visual field defect in the shape of an arc or a scotoma that lies between 10 and 20 degrees from the fixation point. It is associated with glaucomatous damage, and a Bjerrum scotoma can be considered a form of arcuate scotoma.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Seidel scotoma: Paracentral scotoma joins blind spot to form sickle shaped scotoma

 

Option C. Double arcuate scotoma: This refers to a scenario where there are Two Arcuate Scotomas in the Same Eye, which could occur in Advanced Glaucoma.

 

Option D. Paracentral scotoma: These are Small, Round, or Oval areas of visual Field Loss that occur near the Center of the visual field but do not arch around the central vision like Arcuate Scotomas do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify a Superior Arcuate Scotoma as a Bjerrum Scotoma, which is a characteristic Visual Field Defect arcing around the Central Vision, typically associated with Glaucomatous Damage.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 232

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with acute onset of right-sided facial paralysis, severe ear pain, and a vesicular rash in his right ear. He also reports some hearing loss and vertigo on the same side. His past medical history is significant for chickenpox in childhood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by the reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (CN VII).

 

 

Key Features of Ramsay Hunt Syndrome:

 

Triad of symptoms:

  1. Ipsilateral facial paralysis (similar to Bell’s palsy).

  2. Severe otalgia (ear pain).

  3. Vesicular rash in the external ear, ear canal, or oral mucosa.

Additional symptoms:

  • Hearing loss and vertigo (due to involvement of the vestibulocochlear nerve - CN VIII).

  • Tinnitus and altered taste sensation (chorda tympani involvement).

  • Dry eyes and mouth (due to autonomic involvement of CN VII).

Management:

  • Oral Acyclovir or Valacyclovir (antiviral therapy).

  • Systemic corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone to reduce inflammation and nerve damage).

  • Analgesics for pain control.

  • Artificial tears and eye protection (to prevent corneal damage from incomplete eye closure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bell’s Palsy:

  • Incorrect, because Bell’s palsy is an isolated facial nerve palsy without other cranial nerve involvement.

  • It does not cause vesicular rash, ear pain, or hearing loss, which are seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

 

Option B. Acute Otitis Media (AOM):

  • Incorrect, because AOM can cause ear pain but does not cause facial paralysis or vesicular rash.

  • AOM is typically associated with fever, bulging tympanic membrane, and conductive hearing loss, which are absent in this case.

 

 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma):

  • Incorrect, because acoustic neuromas cause progressive, not acute, hearing loss.

  • They do not cause facial paralysis or vesicular rash.

  • Symptoms are gradual and include hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus, rather than sudden onset.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and a vesicular rash in the ear or oral mucosa. It can also involve the vestibulocochlear nerve, causing hearing loss and vertigo. Early treatment with antivirals and corticosteroids improves outcomes.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with acute onset of severe ear pain and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals multiple blisters on the tympanic membrane. This presentation is most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Myringitis bullosa

 

Option A: 

 

Myringitis Bullosa is characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane and can be associated with severe ear pain and temporary hearing loss. It is often seen in conjunction with viral upper respiratory tract infections or as a manifestation of viral infections such as influenza. Mycoplasma pneumonia is supposed to be the causative. Ofcourse, bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae, Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus are also known causatives. The blebs are formed in between the middle and outer layers of tympanic membrane. Most commonly, it is a self-limiting disease. Antibiotics and steroids can be suggested, if required.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Acute otitis media typically presents with ear pain, hearing loss, and a red, bulging tympanic membrane, but without the vesicles or blisters that are characteristic of myringitis bullosa.

 

 

Option C: Cholesteatoma is a chronic condition characterized by the accumulation of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear, which can lead to hearing loss and discharge. It does not present with blisters on the tympanic membrane.

 

 

Option D: Traumatic tympanic membrane perforation is typically associated with sudden sharp ear pain followed by relief and possibly hearing loss, but it is not characterized by the presence of blisters on the tympanic membrane.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis bullosa is a condition characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane, often associated with severe ear pain and temporary hearing loss, and commonly seen in the context of viral infections.

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg55

choices.text: AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss
Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED
Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness
Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness

 

  • The Western blot assay for anti-Hsp70 antibodies is not specific but correlates with active disease and response to steroids, making it a useful supportive diagnostic marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. AIED causes progressive, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, not sudden or conductive loss. Vestibular symptoms like vertigo may also be present.

 

Option B. Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED: Incorrect. The first-line treatment is prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day). Methotrexate is reserved for steroid non-responders or those who cannot tolerate steroids.

 

Option D. Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms: Incorrect. According to Moscicki's criteria, progression is defined as a ≥15 dB shift at one frequency or ≥10 dB at two or more consecutive frequencies, or a significant drop in speech discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of anti-Hsp70 antibodies in autoimmune inner ear disease may correlate with active disease and steroid responsiveness, aiding in diagnosis and treatment planning.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 36

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with hoarseness, painful swallowing, and difficulty breathing. On examination, there is tenderness over the anterior neck, flattening of the thyroid prominence, and palpable subcutaneous crepitus that increases with coughing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngotracheal trauma

 

Key features such as hoarseness, odynophagia (painful swallowing), subcutaneous emphysema, and loss of thyroid prominence contour suggest trauma to the larynx or trachea. Flattened thyroid prominence and crepitus between cartilages are classic signs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiglottitis: Incorrect. Typically presents with drooling, muffled voice, high fever, and stridor in a child or adult. Subcutaneous emphysema and palpable fractures are not features.

 

 

Option C. Retropharyngeal abscess: Incorrect. Common in children, presents with fever, neck stiffness, dysphagia, and bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall—but not crepitus or cartilage fractures.

 

 

Option D. Peritonsillar abscess: Incorrect. Characterized by unilateral sore throat, uvular deviation, trismus, and muffled voice—does not cause subcutaneous emphysema or thyroid cartilage flattening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngotracheal trauma presents with hoarseness, painful swallowing, subcutaneous emphysema, and altered neck contour due to cartilage displacement or fracture.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

questions.text: Which of the following theories of cholesteatoma origin involves retraction pocket formation due to invagination of tympanic membrane epithelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wittmaack’s theory

 

Cholesteatoma is defined as the presence of keratinizing squamous epithelium within the middle ear cleft, where it is not normally present. Several theories have been proposed to explain its origin, particularly how this epithelium gains access to the middle ear.

 

Key Theories of Cholesteatoma Formation:

 

  1. Wittmaack’s Theory (Invagination Theory)
    • Describes formation of retraction pockets from attic or posterosuperior pars tensa
    • Outer epithelium invaginates and lays down keratin
    • Most widely accepted in acquired cholesteatoma
  2. Ruedi’s Theory (Basal Cell Hyperplasia)
    • Infection stimulates basal cell proliferation
    • Forms keratinizing squamous epithelium
  3. Habermann’s Theory (Epithelial Invasion)
    • Squamous epithelium migrates from EAC into middle ear via pre-existing marginal perforation
  4. Sade’s Theory (Metaplasia Theory)
    • Respiratory epithelium of middle ear undergoes metaplasia to squamous epithelium due to chronic infection
  5. Congenital Theory
    • Epithelial rests remain in the middle ear from embryonic development and give rise to cholesteatoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ruedi’s theory:  Basal cell proliferation theory, not retraction

 

Option C. Sade’s theory: Involves metaplasia, not invagination

 

Option D. Habermann’s theory: Involves epithelial migration through a perforation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wittmaack’s theory explains cholesteatoma formation due to retraction pocket of tympanic membrane epithelium invaginating into the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting resembling atrophic rhinitis
Painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower external nose and upper lip
Nasal septal perforation with severe nasal bleeding and ulceration
Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress without any nasal deformity

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is characteristic of the granulomatous stage of rhinoscleroma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower external nose and upper lip

 

The granulomatous stage is marked by the formation of painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules in the nasal mucosa. Additionally, subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and upper lip gives a characteristic “woody” feel.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting resembling atrophic rhinitis: Incorrect. This describes the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma, which resembles atrophic rhinitis and is characterized by foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

 

Option C. Nasal septal perforation with severe nasal bleeding and ulceration: Incorrect. Ulceration and severe nasal bleeding are not typical features of rhinoscleroma; the nodules are usually painless and nonulcerative. Nasal septal perforation is more commonly seen in other diseases like Wegener’s granulomatosis.

 

Option D. Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress without any nasal deformity: Incorrect. Subglottic stenosis causing respiratory distress is a feature of the cicatricial stage of rhinoscleroma, which also involves adhesions and distortion of nasal and pharyngeal structures. Nasal deformity is usually present by this stage.

 

Additional facts:

 

  • Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, a Gram-negative bacillus, and is endemic in many parts of the world, especially the northern parts of India.
  • The disease affects both sexes and all age groups.
  • It progresses through three stages: atrophic, granulomatous, and cicatricial.
  • Early recognition and treatment can prevent progression to the cicatricial stage and its complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The granulomatous stage of rhinoscleroma is characterized by painless, nonulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal “woody” infiltration of the lower nose and upper lip.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 156

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of painless, gradually progressive reduction of vision of the right eye over several months. IOP was OD: 55mmHg and OS: 19mmHg. Anterior chamber was of normal depth in both eyes. A white flaky disc was seen on the anterior lens capsule after dilatation in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudo-Exfoliation Glaucoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Exfoliation Syndrome (XFS)/ Pseudo-Exfoliation Syndrome are an age-related disease characterized by the production and progressive accumulation of Fibrillar Extracellular Material in Ocular Tissues.
  • Glaucoma in Pseudo-Exfoliation can exhibit as Open-Angle or Angle-Closure Glaucoma.

 

Characteristic features are:

 

  • Lens: The most commonly recognized feature is the 3-ring sign on the anterior lens capsule formed by a central disc, a peripheral ring, and a clear zone, in between.
  • Iris: Fine flaky white material can be seen on the pupillary border of the iris without dilation
  • Pupil: Eyes with XFS often dilate poorly.
  • Zonules and Ciliary Body: Exfoliation material (XFM) may be detected earliest on the ciliary processes and zonules and this creates a tendency for spontaneous subluxation or dislocation of the crystalline lens in advanced cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Uveitis Glaucoma is secondary to uveitis. Signs of active inflammation, such as cells and flare in the anterior chamber or synechiae (adhesion of the iris to the lens or cornea), might be expected.

 

Option C. Pigmentary glaucoma is caused by the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris into aqueous humor. This pigment can clog the trabecular meshwork, increasing intraocular pressure. Typical signs include mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects, dense pigmentation of the trabecular meshwork, and a Krukenberg spindle (a vertical deposition of pigment on the corneal endothelium).

 

Option D. Traumatic glaucoma can occur following an injury to the eye and can present with various signs depending on the mechanism of injury. Features might include irregularities of the pupil, signs of angle recession.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characterized by Flaky, Dandruff-like material depositing on the lens, Pupillary Border, and other structures within the eye. This material can be visualized during an Eye Examination and can lead to Increased Intraocular Pressure.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 250

choices.text: It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it
It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus
It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it
It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes MacEwen’s triangle, a key surgical landmark in mastoid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

 

MacEwen’s triangle is a key surgical surface landmark used during mastoidectomy to locate the mastoid antrum, especially in pediatric cases where landmarks can be variable.

 

  • The mastoid antrum lies about 1.5 cm deep to MacEwen’s triangle, making it an essential guide in mastoid surgeries.
  • This triangle is located behind the external auditory canal and guides safe entry during cortical mastoidectomy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it: Incorrect

 

  • The facial recess lies within the middle ear, not related to MacEwen’s triangle.
  • The facial recess is identified between the facial nerve and chorda tympani, not through surface landmarks.

 

Option B. It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus:  Incorrect

 

  • The actual boundaries of MacEwen’s triangle are:
    • Anteriorly: Posterosuperior meatal wall
    • Superiorly: Temporal line
    • Posteriorly: A vertical tangent to the posterior canal wall
  • The zygomatic arch and sigmoid sinus are unrelated to its boundaries.

 

Option D. It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube: Incorrect

 

  • These landmarks are not related to the triangle.
  • The temporal line, not the parietal eminence, forms the superior boundary, and the Eustachian tube is not part of the surface triangle anatomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacEwen’s triangle is a surface landmark bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, temporal line, and a posterior tangent to the external canal, used to identify the mastoid antrum located approximately 1.5 cm deep to it.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5,6

choices.text: Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting
Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks
Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a long history of voice abuse and smoking presents with gradually progressive hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral fusiform, translucent swellings over the membranous vocal cords consistent with Reinke’s edema. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks

 

This is the standard surgical treatment for Reinke’s edema. The procedure involves removing a strip of edematous mucosa (decortication). It is done one side at a time to preserve airway and voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting: Can lead to airway compromise and poor voice outcome. Not recommended.

 

Option C. Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle : Used in spasmodic dysphonia, not Reinke’s edema.

 

Option D. Cordectomy with laser:  Too aggressive for benign lesions like Reinke’s edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s edema is treated surgically by staged unilateral decortication of the vocal cords to remove edematous mucosa while preserving voice and airway.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient visited the ophthalmologist with complaints of Red, Watery Eyes with a slight gritty sensation since the past 10 days. After examination, he is diagnosed with Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis. Which Adenovirus Serotype is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 8 & 19.

 

Option D: 

 

Epidemic Kerato Conjunctivitis is caused by ADENOVIRUS serotypes- 8 & 19.

 

Other clinical features:

 

  • Associated with Keratitis and Preauricular Lymphadenopathy

  • Pseudomembrane lining the lower fornix.

  • Follicles in lower palpebral conjunctiva & fornix

  • SPKs-Superficial punctate keratitis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serotypes 10 & 12: These serotypes are not typically associated with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Adenovirus serotypes 10 and 12 are more commonly associated with respiratory illnesses.

 

Option B. Serotypes 3 & 7: These serotypes can cause various adenoviral infections, including some forms of conjunctivitis, but they are not the most common causes of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Serotypes 3 & 8: Serotype 3 is associated with a range of adenoviral infections, including conjunctivitis, but serotype 8 is one of the primary serotypes known to cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotypes 8 & 19 of adenovirus are most frequently responsible for cases of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, which is characterized by symptoms like red, watery eyes and a gritty sensation.

 

Ref: Pg 74/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to a pediatric ophthalmology clinic with enlarged and cloudy corneas, excessive tearing, and light sensitivity. Examination reveals increased intraocular pressure, corneal edema, and increased cup:disc ratio of the optic nerve head. The diagnosis of developmental glaucoma (congenital glaucoma) is made. All of the following drugs can be given to lower the IOP except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brimonidine

 

Option C.

 

  • Brimonidine is an alpha-agonist that reduces the production of aqueous humour and increases aqueous outflow via uveoscleral pathway.
  • It can cross blood-brain barrier and cause drowsiness and respiratory depression in infants and children and is therefore contraindicated in them.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous humour production. It is generally considered safe and can be used in infants to lower IOP.

 

Option B. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue used to increase the outflow of aqueous humour, thereby lowering IOP. It is generally safe for use in infants, although monitoring for potential side effects like iris hyperpigmentation is important.

 

Option D. Betaxolol is a beta-blocker used in glaucoma to reduce aqueous humour production. It is generally safe for use in infants, although, like all systemic beta-blockers, it requires monitoring for potential respiratory and cardiovascular effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brimonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humour production and increases uveoscleral outflow, is not recommended for use in infants and young children due to the risk of severe side effects, including respiratory problems, lethargy, and decreased heart rate. It is contraindicated in children under the age of 2 years.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page: 157

choices.text: Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration
Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation
Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window
Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly explains the importance of phase differential between the oval and round windows in the auditory system?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

 

  • The phase differential between the oval and round windows—achieved via the ossicular chain, tympanic membrane, and air cushion around the round window—ensures that when compression hits the oval window, the round window bulges outward (rarefaction). This creates the necessary fluid movement in the cochlea for sound transduction and contributes about 4 dB to hearing efficiency when the tympanic membrane is intact.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration: Incorrect. If sound waves reach both windows simultaneously, the compressions and rarefactions would cancel each other out, leading to no effective movement of perilymph, and hence no hearing.

 

Option B. Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation: Incorrect. The ossicular chain transmits sound to the oval window, not the round window. The round window acts as a pressure release point.

 

Option C. Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window: Incorrect. Compression at the oval window is paired with rarefaction at the round window, creating fluid displacement inside the cochlea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase differential between the oval and round windows ensures alternate compression and rarefaction, preventing cancellation of waves and enabling perilymph movement for effective hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13.

questions.text: Which is the thickest wall of the orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral wall

 

Option B:

 

  • Lateral orbital wall is made up of- zygomatic bone, greater wing of sphenoid.

  • It is the thickest & strongest orbital wall.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medial Wall: The medial wall of the orbit is one of the thinnest and most fragile parts. It is formed primarily by the ethmoid bone and partly by the lacrimal bone, the frontal bone, and the lesser wing of the sphenoid. This wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells, making it prone to injury and subsequent communication with the nasal cavity.

 

 

Option C. Roof: The roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate of the frontal bone and, to a lesser extent, by the lesser wing of the sphenoid. It separates the orbital contents from the anterior cranial fossa and provides protection from superior impacts. It's relatively thin compared to the lateral wall but stronger than the medial wall.

 

 

Option D. Floor: The floor of the orbit is formed by the orbital surface of the maxillary bone, along with small contributions from the zygomatic bone and the palatine bone. This wall is thin and vulnerable to fractures, especially from trauma to the orbit, as it separates the orbital contents from the maxillary sinus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit, providing substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts, and distinguishing itself in strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall, the moderately strong roof, and the thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit.

 

Ref: pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: IV antibiotics and emergency incision and drainage
Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild dysphagia, posterior throat discomfort, and a gradually enlarging midline swelling on the posterior pharyngeal wall. He also has multiple cervical lymph nodes and a history of weight loss and low-grade fever. Cervical spine X-ray reveals destruction of C3 and C4 vertebral bodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

 

This is the standard treatment for tubercular prevertebral abscesses.

 

This is a classic presentation of a chronic retropharyngeal abscess (specifically a prevertebral abscess) due to tuberculosis:

 

  • Most commonly caused by cervical spine tuberculosis (Pott’s disease)
  • Abscess lies behind the prevertebral fascia, usually midline
  • Often has minimal symptoms like mild dysphagia and throat discomfort
  • Cervical spine X-ray is diagnostic (shows vertebral destruction)
  • May be associated with tuberculous cervical lymphadenopathy

 

Management:

 

  • Incision and drainage via:
    • Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (for low abscesses)
    • Posterior border (for high abscesses)
  • Full course of ATT (antitubercular therapy) is essential to prevent recurrence and control infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV antibiotics and emergency drainage: Suitable for acute pyogenic abscess, not tubercular. Also, ATT is essential.

 

Option C. Oral steroids and observation: Steroids may worsen TB if given alone; definitive drainage and ATT are necessary.

 

Option D. Immediate tracheostomy: Airway obstruction is not typical in chronic prevertebral TB abscess. Tracheostomy is reserved for acute airway compromise, e.g., in Ludwig’s angina or acute retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess due to cervical spine tuberculosis is treated with incision and drainage followed by a full course of antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

choices.text: Incision and drainage with bilateral nasal packing
Reassure and follow-up after a week

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and headache after a fall during a football match. On anterior rhinoscopy, a smooth, soft, fluctuant swelling is seen on both sides of the septum. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage with bilateral nasal packing

 

This is the treatment of choice for large septal haematomas. Drainage prevents complications like septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and saddle nose deformity. Packing prevents reaccumulation of blood, and antibiotics are given to prevent infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe oral decongestants and monitor: Incorrect. This approach delays definitive treatment. Septal haematomas can lead to cartilage necrosis and deformity if not drained promptly.

 

Option C. Immediate septoplasty: Incorrect. Septoplasty is indicated for deviated nasal septum, not for haematoma. Surgical drainage is sufficient unless structural deformity develops later.

 

Option D. Reassure and follow-up after a week: Incorrect. Delay in treatment may lead to secondary infection and irreversible cartilage damage. Timely intervention is critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal haematoma must be promptly incised and drained with nasal packing to prevent complications like septal abscess and saddle nose deformity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 149

choices.text: SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma
The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments
A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology
Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

 

  • Patients with cochlear hearing loss (e.g., Ménière’s disease, presbycusis) have increased sensitivity to small intensity changes, resulting in SISI scores of 70–100%, which is diagnostic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma: Incorrect. Retrocochlear (nerve) lesions typically produce low SISI scores (0–20%) because these patients have poor sensitivity to small intensity changes.

 

Option B. The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments: Incorrect. In the SISI test, a continuous pure tone is presented 20 dB above threshold, and every 5 seconds a 1 dB increment (blip) is introduced — not 5 dB.

 

Option D. Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%: Incorrect. In conductive hearing loss, SISI scores are usually <15%, as sound conduction is impaired but cochlear function remains intact.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A SISI score of 70–100% is indicative of cochlear pathology, helping differentiate it from retrocochlear and conductive causes of hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: This fundus appearance is seen in which form of refractive error?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

Option A.

 

This fundus picture shows:

 

  • Mild tilting of disc
  • Characteristic temporal crescent
  • Grossly tessellated background

 

All these above-mentioned features are suggestive of Myopia.

 

Additional features:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypermetropia: Optic Disc: The optic nerve head may appear smaller or may have a crowded appearance due to the smaller eye size typically associated with hypermetropia. This can sometimes be mistaken for papilledema, which is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure.

 

Option C. Astigmatism: There is no characteristic fundus findings in eyes with astigmatism.

 

Option D. Presbyopia: There are no characteristic findings in eyes with presbyopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tessellated fundus is most commonly seen in myopia, as the retinal thinning associated with this condition makes the choroidal vessels more apparent, giving the retina its characteristic mosaic-like appearance.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 35

choices.text: Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery
Freer’s elevator – used to elevate tympanomeatal flap
Myringotome – used for incision in tympanic membrane
Mollison’s retractor – used for soft tissue retraction in postaural mastoidectomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery

 

  • The instrument shown is Lempert’s curette (also called Lempert’s scoop). It has a rounded scoop-like end and is commonly used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa between air cells and clear out granulation tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Freer’s elevator: Freer’s elevator is a double-ended blunt instrument used to elevate flaps, especially during septoplasty, not for bone or granulation removal.

 

 

Option C. Myringotome: A myringotome is a fine angled knife used to make a precise incision in the tympanic membrane, not to remove bone or granulations.

 

 

Option D. Mollison’s retractor: This is a self-retaining retractor used for soft tissue retraction in postaural approaches, not a curette.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lempert’s curette is used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa and granulation tissue from the mastoid air cells.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presented with complaints of decrease in vision in both eyes. He also give history of itching and irritation in both eyes, on and off. On examination, the conjunctiva shows cobblestone papillae and discrete white dots along the limbus. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis

 

Option D: 

 

POINTS IN FAVOUR:

 

  • 15-year-old Male

  • Cobble Stone Papillae

  • Horner Tranta Spots (discrete White Dots along the Limbus)

  • Other features as disease progresses: Superior Punctate Epithelial Erosions, Shield Ulcers, Pseudogerontoxon.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis:

 

  • Occurs as an allergic response to endogenous allergens (Tuberculous proteins, Staphylococcal proteins).

  • Most of the times there is solitary conjunctival nodule but at times there may be two nodules. In a few days the nodule ulcerates at apex which later on gets epithelised.

 

Option B. Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis:

 

  • Follicles: more marked in lower lid

  • Pseudomembrane on the conjunctival surface

  • Superficial punctuate keratitis: distinctive feature of EKC, becomes apparent after 1 week of the onset of disease

  • Preauricular lymphadenopathy

 

Option C. Cicatricial Conjunctivitis:

 

  • Chronic conjunctivitis with conjunctival fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of Cobblestone Papillae and Horner Trantas Spots  are suggestive of a diagnosis of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis.

choices.text: Teflon injection into the vocal cord

questions.text: A 50-year-old male underwent thyroid surgery 3 months ago. He now presents with mild hoarseness of voice but no aspiration or breathing difficulty. Flexible laryngoscopy shows a left vocal cord in paramedian position with partial compensation by the right cord. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Observation and voice therapy

 

Since many patients compensate over time and temporary paralysis may recover within 6–12 months, waiting and supportive therapy is appropriate. Gelfoam/fat injection may be considered if voice is significantly impaired during this period.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teflon injection into the vocal cord: Not preferred currently due to foreign body reaction and stiffness. It was used previously for permanent medialization.

Option B. Immediate Type I thyroplasty: Type I thyroplasty is for persistent symptoms and posterior glottic incompetence. It is not indicated immediately, especially when spontaneous recovery is possible in 6–12 months.

Option D. Arytenoid adduction surgery: Reserved for cases where posterior glottis is also incompetent and medialization is inadequate with thyroplasty alone. Not the first-line approach in early or mild unilateral paralysis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Most cases of unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis improve spontaneously and are managed conservatively for the first 6–12 months.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

choices.text: By fibrous bands at two points of contact
By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery
Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule
By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane

questions.text: How is the stapes footplate attached to the oval window of the cochlea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

 

The stapes is the third and innermost ossicle in the middle ear, and its footplate plays a critical role in transmitting sound vibrations into the inner ear:

 

  • The footplate of the stapes fits into the oval window (fenestra vestibuli) of the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • It is held in place by the annular ligament, which attaches around the entire periphery of the footplate in a circumferential manner.
  • This allows the footplate to vibrate and transmit mechanical energy to the perilymph of the scala vestibuli in the cochlea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By fibrous bands at two points of contact: Incorrect

 

  • There are no two-point fibrous attachments; the connection is circular and uniform, not focal.

 

Option C. Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule: Incorrect

 

  • A bony fusion at this site would impede movement, as occurs in otosclerosis.
  • Under normal conditions, the stapes is not fused, but freely mobile, thanks to the annular ligament.

 

Option D. By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane: Incorrect

 

  • The round window is located below the oval window, and is unrelated to stapes attachment.
  • It acts as a pressure-release valve during cochlear fluid movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stapes footplate is attached to the oval window via the annular ligament in a circumferential manner, allowing sound transmission to the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct
Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone
Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis
The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with recurrent frontal headaches, especially in the mornings, and tenderness above the supraorbital margin. CT scan shows mucosal thickening in the frontal sinus and blockage of the frontal recess. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the anatomy and drainage of the frontal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis

 

Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct: Incorrect. It drains into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontal recess. The term “nasofrontal duct” is outdated and incorrect as no true duct exists.

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Morning frontal headaches
  • Tenderness above the supraorbital margin
  • CT evidence of frontal sinusitis with frontal recess obstruction

 

The frontal sinus lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, situated between the inner and outer tables of the frontal bone. Its drainage pathway is through the frontal ostium into the frontal recess, which is anatomically bounded by:

 

  • Middle turbinate (medially)
  • Lamina papyracea (laterally)
  • Agger nasi cells (anteriorly)
  • Bulla ethmoidalis (posteriorly)

 

Obstruction of this narrow and often tortuous drainage pathway by anterior ethmoidal cells can cause frontal sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone: Incorrect. It lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, within the frontal bone, not ethmoid bone.

 

Option C. Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis: Correct. This relationship defines the anatomy of the frontal recess, and is crucial in understanding obstruction mechanisms in frontal sinusitis.

 

Option D. The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals: Incorrect. The septum is often thin, oblique, or even absent, and the two sinuses are often asymmetrical.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus drains into the middle meatus via the frontal recess, which is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of severe headache, fever, and double vision. She recently had a dental abscess treated. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, and her visual examination shows impaired lateral movement of the right eye. There is no ptosis or pupillary abnormality. Her facial sensation is intact. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows evidence suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

 

 

Which cranial nerve is most likely involved first in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abducent

 

Option C:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis causes painful ophthalmoplegia involving the following cranial nerves:

 

  • III (Oculomotor)

  • IV (Trochlear)

  • VI (Abducent) (1st to be involved as it passes through the sinus)

  • V (I) (Ophthalmic branch of Trigeminal nerve)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor (Cranial Nerve III): This nerve controls most of the eye's movements, the constriction of the pupil, and maintains an open eyelid. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, its involvement typically results in ptosis (drooping eyelid), pupillary dilation, and limited eye movement except for lateral and downward gaze.

 

Option B. Trochlear (Cranial Nerve IV): This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for downward and lateral eye movement. Its involvement would lead to vertical diplopia, particularly when looking down.

 

Option D. Trigeminal (Cranial Nerve V): This nerve is responsible for facial sensation and motor functions of the muscles of mastication. Involvement in cavernous sinus thrombosis would cause facial sensory loss and chewing difficulties but not eye movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cavernous sinus thrombosis, the abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) is typically the earliest to be affected due to its vulnerability within the cavernous sinus, often presenting with an inability to abduct the eye and resulting in horizontal diplopia.

 

Ref: pg 412,6th edition, comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

choices.text: Immediate open reduction and plating of thyroid cartilage fracture
Endotracheal intubation followed by conservative management
Surgical repair with open reduction, cartilage wiring, and mucosal repair within 3–5 days
Observation only, as the tracheostomy is already done

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents 24 hours after sustaining blunt trauma to the neck in a bike accident. He has hoarseness, subcutaneous emphysema, and CT shows a displaced fracture of the thyroid cartilage with mucosal tear. He is breathing comfortably via tracheostomy. What is the most appropriate surgical approach at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical repair with open reduction, cartilage wiring, and mucosal repair within 3–5 days

 

This is the standard timing and protocol for operative repair: reduce cartilage fractures, repair mucosa, stabilize with wires or miniplates, and consider internal splinting if needed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate open reduction and plating of thyroid cartilage fracture: Incorrect. Immediate repair may be complicated by edema; ideal timing is 3–5 days after injury once swelling reduces.

 

Option B. Endotracheal intubation followed by conservative management: Incorrect. Intubation is not preferred in laryngeal trauma due to risk of worsening injury. Tracheostomy is safer and already done here.

 

Option D. Observation only, as the tracheostomy is already done: Incorrect. Without definitive repair, long-term sequelae like stenosis or poor voice outcomes may occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open surgical repair of laryngeal trauma is ideally done within 3–5 days and includes cartilage reduction, mucosal repair, and internal stenting when needed.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 288

choices.text: Pseudopterygium is due to an Inflammatory Process
A probe can be passed underneath a Pterygium
Neoplasm can occur in a Long-Standing Pterygium

questions.text: Identify the False Statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A Probe can be passed underneath a Pterygium

 

Pterygium:

 

  • It is a non-malignant slow growing proliferation of wing shaped fibrovascular tissue.

  • Arises from subconjunctival tissue.

  • RISK FACTORS - warm, dry climate, UV exposure

  • A probe cannot be passed underneath a pterygium.

  • Complications:

    1. Cystic degeneration

    2. Neoplasm- Epithelioma, Malignant Melanoma

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudopterygium is due to an inflammatory process: This is true. Pseudopterygium occurs as a result of an inflammatory process, often secondary to trauma or surgery, leading to the adhesion of the conjunctiva to the underlying cornea. A probe can be passed under pseudopterygium.

 

Option C. Pterygium occurs in the palpebral aperture: This statement is true. Pterygium commonly occurs in the palpebral aperture, particularly in the area exposed to sunlight and wind, often on the nasal side.

 

Option D. Long standing pterygium can develop epithelioma or malignant melanoma as reported in literature. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Probe can't be passed beneath a true pterygium, but can be passed under a pseudo pterygium, which generally occurs secondary to inflammatory process. Although very rare, but development of neoplasm in long-standing pterygium has been reported.

 

Ref:

  1. Pg 88/CONJUNCTIVA/Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/6th Edition.

  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK558907/#:~:text=A%20'probe'%20test%20can%20be,is%20non%2Dprogressive%20in%20nature.&text=It%20is%20a%20yellowish%20colored,conjunctiva%20close%20to%20the%20limbus.

questions.text: Identify the type of lens in this picture:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigid Gas Permeable Lens

 

Option B:

 

  • Oxygen-permeable or rigid gas-permeable lenses are made of a firm, durable plastic that transmits oxygen.
  • Materials used include copolymer of PMMA and silicone and cellulose acetate butyrate.
  • As they do not contain water, they resist deposits and are less likely than soft contact lenses to harbor bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Soft Contact Lens: Made of soft, flexible plastics that allow oxygen to pass through to the cornea, soft contact lenses are comfortable and easier to adapt to than rigid lenses.

 

Option C. Hard Contact Lens: Made of a rigid, durable plastic, hard contact lenses are less comfortable and less oxygen-permeable compared to soft or rigid gas permeable lenses and are rarely used today.

 

Option D. Scleral Contact Lens: Large-diameter lenses that vault over the entire corneal surface and rest on the sclera, scleral lenses are used for specific corneal irregularities and provide comfort for sensitive eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid Gas Permeable Lens: are more durable than soft contact lenses, provide clearer vision, and are breathable, allowing more oxygen to reach the cornea.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 82

questions.text: The type of optic atrophy seen in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consecutive

 

Option C:

 

  • The fundus picture shows retinitis pigmentosa.

  • There occurs consecutive optic atrophy characterized by waxy pallor of the optic disc.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consecutive optic neuropathy is a form of optic nerve damage resulting as a consequence of pathologies of retina and uvea. It is characterized by progressive axonal loss leading to optic atrophy, visual impairment, and optic disc pallor on examination. Management focuses on treating the underlying cause and supporting vision with aids if necessary.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 753

choices.text:
A. Nasal Shift of Vessels   
B. Bayonetting

A. Temporal Shift of Vessels  
B. Bayoneting

A. Bayoneting   
B. Laminar Dot Sign

A. Bayoneting   
B. Baring of Circum Linear Vessels

questions.text: What are the Glaucomatous changes shown in the below figures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A Nasal Shift of Vessels   B. Bayonetting

 

These are the Optic Disc changes seen in Glaucoma.

 

Optic Disc changes in Glaucoma

 

  • Cupping- Excavation of the Cup
  • Thinning of Neuro Retinal Rim
  • Nasal Shifting of vessels
  • Bayonetting- appearance of vessel being broken off at the margin
  • Laminar Dot Sign- visible pores in Lamina Cribrosa
  • Pulsation of Retinal Arterioles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that Nasal Shifting of Blood Vessels and Bayonetting, which are indicative of Nerve Fiber Layer Loss, are hallmark signs of Glaucomatous Optic Neuropathy observable upon examination of the Optic Disc.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 231

questions.text: All of the following are features of trachoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobblestone Papillae

 

Option B.

 

Cobblestone papillae are seen in VKC.

 

  • Features of trachoma include:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herbert Pits are small, shallow depressions found on the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera) in the advanced stages of trachoma. They are the result of resolved limbal follicles and are a characteristic sign of chronic or healed trachoma. This feature is indeed associated with trachoma.

 

Option C. Artl’s Line is a scar line seen in the sulcus subtarsalis in the upper eyelid in chronic trachoma. It is formed due to the healing of conjunctival scarring and is a sign of advanced disease. This feature is a part of trachoma's presentation.

 

Option D. Trichiasis refers to the inward turning of the eyelashes, which rub against the cornea and conjunctiva, causing irritation and potential corneal damage. Trichiasis is a common complication of chronic trachoma due to scarring of the eyelid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cobblestone papillae are not a feature of Trachoma.

 

Ref: Pg 68/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

 

Option C:

 

This condition, characterized by a difference in color between the two irises, is not typically a feature of adult-onset Horner's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with congenital Horner's syndrome, where the condition is present from birth or early childhood.

 

Causes of HORNER’S SYNDROME:

 

  • Ptosis

  • Miosis

  • Heterochromia iridis

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.

 

Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face. It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.

 

Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.

 

Conclusion:

 

Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.

 

Ref: pg344/anatomy & physiology of eye 3rd edition – ak Khurana (pg 575)

choices.text: The membranous septum lies posterior to the perpendicular plate of ethmoid
The columellar septum is made up of septal cartilage and covered by nasal mucosa
The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the bony part of the septum proper
The membranous septum is supported by the vomer and palatine crest

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes a component of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The perpendicular plate of ethmoid contributes to the bony part of the septum proper

 

  • It forms the superior portion of the osteocartilaginous septum proper.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The membranous septum lies posterior to the perpendicular plate of ethmoid: Incorrect. The membranous septum lies anterior to the septal cartilage, not posterior to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid.

 

Option B. The columellar septum is made up of septal cartilage and covered by nasal mucosa: Incorrect. The columellar septum consists of the medial crura of the alar cartilages, united by fibrous tissue and covered by skin, not mucosa.

 

Option D. The membranous septum is supported by the vomer and palatine crest: Incorrect. The membranous septum has no bony or cartilaginous support, consisting only of skin layers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The perpendicular plate of ethmoid is a major bony component of the septum proper, forming the superior part of the nasal septum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 147

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the innervation of the tympanic membrane. Which nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Option A: 

 

The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is itself a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), is responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane. This innervation is important for the sensation of pain, temperature, and touch in this region of the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) does provide some innervation to the tympanic membrane, particularly to the outer posterior half surface via the auricular branch (also known as Arnold's nerve), but it is not primarily responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option C: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) innervates a portion of the tympanic membrane, particularly the inner surface, via its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). However, it is not the main nerve supplying the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is mainly responsible for motor innervation in the facial region and does not provide sensory innervation to the tympanic membrane. Via nervus intermedius (sensory fibres of facial nerve), it supplies posterior wall of external auditory canal. This nerve is responsible for hitselberger sign in acoustic neuroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane is provided by the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).

 

Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg4

choices.text: Incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing
Immediate referral for plastic surgery consultation

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen left ear following a physical altercation. On examination, the left auricle is markedly swollen and deformed with a fluctuant, non-erythematous area occupying most of the antihelical fold. There is no laceration or discharge, and the patient denies any hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and Drainage Followed by Pressure Dressing

 

The given case describes a 22-year-old male with a swollen, fluctuant auricle following trauma, which is characteristic of an auricular hematoma.

 

  • Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma leading to blood accumulation between the perichondrium and auricular cartilage.
  • The best management is incision and drainage (I&D) followed by a pressure dressing to:
    • Evacuate the hematoma and prevent re-accumulation.
    • Maintain blood supply to the cartilage and prevent necrosis.
    • Minimize the risk of "cauliflower ear" deformity (fibrotic, deformed auricle due to chronic hematoma).

 

Procedure:

 

  1. Local anesthesia is administered.
  2. Small incision or needle aspiration to drain the hematoma.
  3. Pressure dressing is applied to prevent hematoma reformation.
  4. Antibiotics (to prevent perichondritis) may be prescribed in some cases.
  5. Follow-up is necessary to check for recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cold Compress and Analgesics: Incorrect because symptomatic treatment alone does not evacuate the hematoma. Persistent blood accumulation can cause cartilage necrosis and fibrosis, leading to a cauliflower ear deformity.

 

Option C. Oral Antibiotics and Outpatient Follow-up: Incorrect because auricular hematoma is not primarily an infection but a traumatic blood collection. Oral antibiotics do not treat the underlying hematoma, though they may be used to prevent secondary perichondritis.

 

Option D. Immediate Referral for Plastic Surgery Consultation: Incorrect because plastic surgery is not the first-line intervention for an uncomplicated auricular hematoma. Most cases are managed in the emergency or ENT department with incision, drainage, and dressing. Plastic surgery is considered only in cases of failed initial treatment or severe deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Auricular hematomas should be managed promptly with incision and drainage followed by a pressure dressing to prevent cartilage necrosis and permanent deformity (cauliflower ear). 
  • Cold compresses, antibiotics, or plastic surgery consultation alone are not sufficient initial treatments.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angular conjunctivitis

 

Option C: 

 

Characterised by inflammation of conjunctiva & lid margins near the angles.

 

  • Causative organism: MORAXELLA AXENFELD

  • Also called: Diplobacillary conjunctivitis

  • Source of the infection is the nasal cavity, from where it reaches the eyes by contaminated fingers or handkerchief.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis is an immune response often associated with tuberculosis or staphylococcal infection. It is characterized by small, white, nodular lesions (phlyctenules) on the conjunctiva. While it causes discomfort and redness, it does not specifically manifest as angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Hyperacute Conjunctivitis is typically caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Neisseria meningitidis and is characterized by a very rapid onset and severe symptoms, including copious purulent discharge. It does not specifically present as angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Trachoma, chronic infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis leads to follicular conjunctivitis initially and, over time, can cause scarring. Trachoma typically involves the entire conjunctiva and not just the angular areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angular conjunctivitis caused by Moraxella Axenfeld is characterised by inflammation of conjunctiva and lid margins near the angle.

 

Ref: Pg 66/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

choices.text: It supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx
It arises higher in the neck than the right nerve
It has a shorter course than the right nerve
It loops around the aortic arch and has a longer intrathoracic course

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains why the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury or paralysis than the right?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It loops around the aortic arch and has a longer intrathoracic course

 

This longer course in the mediastinum makes the left recurrent laryngeal nerve more susceptible to injury from thoracic pathologies (e.g., aortic aneurysm, mediastinal tumors).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx: True for both recurrent laryngeal nerves, but does not explain the higher susceptibility of the left nerve.

 

Option B. It arises higher in the neck than the right nerve: Incorrect. In fact, the left arises lower, from the thorax.


Option C. It has a shorter course than the right nerve: Incorrect. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course as it loops around the aortic arch in the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to paralysis due to its longer intrathoracic course, looping around the aortic arch.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of 5 days of progressive left facial swelling and fever. On ocular inspection, left periorbital oedema, erythema and discharge are noted. On examination, left eye showed decrease in visual acuity, and the pupil showed relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

 

Option B:

 

Orbital cellulitis-

 

  • Fever, chills

  • Periorbital edema, erythema, extra ocular movement restriction

  • Optic nerve involvement- decreased vision, RAPD

  • If progresses- intra orbital abscess.

 

Other choices: Usually don’t present with fever, chills, erythema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation): This is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins, bypassing the capillary system. It can cause swelling and other issues due to altered blood flow, but it typically does not present with infection-like symptoms (fever, discharge) or a rapid onset of visual changes and RAPD.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: A malignant tumor of the retina, common in children. It usually presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may cause vision loss. However, retinoblastoma does not typically cause fever, periorbital edema, or erythema, which are indicative of an infectious process.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: A cancer that develops from immature nerve cells, mostly occurring in children. It can present with various symptoms depending on the site of the tumor but is unlikely to cause localized periorbital edema, erythema, and discharge without other systemic or neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pediatric patient presenting with fever, progressive facial swelling, periorbital edema, erythema, discharge, decreased visual acuity, and RAPD, the most probable diagnosis is Orbital Cellulitis, an infectious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the orbital tissues, often requiring prompt medical intervention.

 

Ref: pg 409/ orbit/ 6th edition comprehensive ophthalmology  ak khurana

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with low-grade fever and a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and soft palate. The membrane is adherent and bleeds on attempted removal. There is mild sore throat, and urine analysis reveals albuminuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diphtheria

 

Fits all described features: slow onset, mild pain, adherent membrane, bleeding on removal, soft palate involvement, and albuminuria.

 

  • Diphtheria is classically characterized by:
    • Slow onset and mild local symptoms
    • A dirty grey adherent membrane that extends beyond the tonsils to the soft palate
    • Bleeds on removal
    • Albuminuria (due to systemic toxin effects)
    • Diagnosis confirmed by throat swab showing Corynebacterium diphtheriae

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute membranous tonsillitis:  This may appear similar but the membrane is limited to the tonsils, forms from coalesced exudates in acute follicular tonsillitis, and can usually be removed without bleeding.

 

 

Option C. Vincent angina: Usually unilateral, less fever, and membrane is removable, revealing an irregular ulcer. Fusiform bacilli and spirochetes are seen on Gram stain.

 

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis:  Typically seen in young adults, with bilaterally enlarged tonsils, prominent lymphadenopathy (especially posterior triangle), and splenomegaly. Paul–Bunnell test is positive.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Diphtheria presents with an adherent, dirty grey membrane over the tonsils and soft palate that bleeds on removal and is confirmed by detection of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: A 22-year-old male, came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of pain, redness, watering in the eyes along with photophobia since 2 days. After examination, a diagnosis of haemorrhagic conjunctivitis is made. Which is the most common causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

Option D: Haemorrhagic Conjunctivitis is inflammation of conjunctiva characterised by multiple bulbar conjunctival haemorrhages.

 

  • Cause: Picornavirus (ENTEROVIRUS Type 70) and Coxsackie A24 variant.

  • Clinical features: Follicular hyperplasia, pre-auricular lymphadenopathy

  • Self-limiting course within 5-7 days

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While adenovirus is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis, it typically does not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. The conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus is usually characterized by watery discharge, redness, and follicular conjunctival reaction.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause such as retinitis in immunocompromised individuals, but it is not a typical cause of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) can lead to various ocular complications due to immune suppression. However, it is not directly associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common causative agent of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which presents with symptoms like pain, redness, watering, and photophobia, is Enterovirus, particularly Enterovirus 70 and the Coxsackie A24 variant.

 

Ref:

  1. pg 77/ CONJUNCTIVA/ comprehensive ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

  2. Wright PW, Strauss GH, Langford MP. Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Am Fam Physician. 1992 Jan;45(1):173-8. PMID: 1309404.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurring of vision since the past few months.
