During evaluation, she is subjected to retinoscopic refraction wherein the streak of light and the shadow moved in opposite directions. Based on this, what is the refractive error she is likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myopia >1D.

 

Option D:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypermetropia > 1D: Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, is indicated by "with motion" in retinoscopy (where the light streak and shadow move in the same direction), not "against motion".

 

Option B. Myopia < 1D: Produces with movement.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia < 1D: Similar to option A, hypermetropia would not present with "with motion" in retinoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinoscopy, if the streak of light and the shadow move in opposite directions (against motion), it typically indicates myopia, and the speed of the shadow's movement can help determine the degree of myopia. A quick shadow movement against the light streak suggests myopia greater than 1 diopter.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 59

choices.text: A - iii, B - i, C - iv, D - ii
A - i, B - iii, C - iv, D - ii

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A - iii, B - i, C - iv, D - ii

 

Option A:

 

NODULES IN IRIS

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

As shown in the image, iris nodules are seen in various pathologies.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

questions.text: Which drug causes the given presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical PG Analogues

 

Option C:

 

  • Cystoid Macular Oedema (CMO) results from the accumulation of fluid in the Outer Plexiform and Inner Nuclear Layers of the Retina with the Formation of Tiny Cyst-like Cavities.
  • Causes:
    • Ocular Surgery and Laser, (e.g., Phacoemulsification, PRP)
    • Retinal Vascular Disease, (e.g., Diabetic Retinopathy, Vein Occlusion)
    • Inflammation, (e.g., Intermediate Uveitis, Severe or Chronic Uveitis)
    • Drug-Induced, (e.g., Topical Prostaglandin Derivatives)
    • Retinal Dystrophies, (e.g., Retinitis Pigmentosa)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Topical Steroids are used in the treatment of Cystoid Macular Edema.

 

Option B. Topical Beta Blockers are commonly used for glaucoma treatment and do not typically cause Cystoid Macular Edema. Their primary mechanism of action is reducing aqueous humor production in the eye.

 

Option D. Topical Cycloplegics are used to paralyze the ciliary muscle and dilate the pupil. While they have various effects on the eye, they are not typically associated with causing Cystoid Macular Edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical Prostaglandin Analogues can cause Cystoid Macular Edema.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 602

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of sudden decrease in vision in left eye and pain with movement of eye. On examination, the pupil showed RAPD in left eye and colour vision assessment revealed a red-green deficit. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic neuritis

 

Option A:

 

  • Optic neuritis presents with marked decrease in visual acuity.

  • Loss of red-green colour vision is a common symptom of Optic nerve disease.

  • Pupillary defect – Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD: suggestive of defect in optic nerve or retina)

 

 

  • Most common cause of Optic neuritis in adults in Demyelinating diseases, and among them is Multiple sclerosis (most common in middle-aged females).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Papilledema:

 

  • Description: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. It usually affects both eyes.

  • Relevance to Case: While papilledema can cause visual symptoms, it does not typically present with sudden vision loss or pain with eye movement. RAPD is not a characteristic finding in papilledema.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment:

 

  • Description: Retinal detachment involves the separation of the neurosensoryretina from its Retinal Pigment Epithelium. Symptoms include floaters, flashes of light, and a "curtain" over part of the field of vision.

  • Relevance to Case: The sudden decrease in vision could suggest retinal detachment, but the pain with eye movement and RAPD are not typical features of this condition. Also, retinal detachment does not usually affect color vision.

 

Option D. CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion):

 

  • Description: CRAO is an occlusion of the central retinal artery leading to acute, painless vision loss in one eye.

  • Relevance to Case: The sudden loss of vision is consistent with CRAO, but the presence of pain with eye movement is not typical associated with CRAO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden decrease in vision, pain with movement of the eye, RAPD, and a red-green color vision deficit are classic signs of Optic Neuritis. MRI is the imaging modality of choice and treatment is pulse IV Methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by oral corticosteroids.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 314

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmia is currently receiving treatment with Amiodarone. The patient complains of defective vision, prompting an ophthalmic evaluation. Given the patient's medication history, what is the probable form of cataract that may be observed in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior Subcapsular Cataract

 

Option A:

 

  • Amiodarone is a class 3 antiarrythmic.
  • Mechanism of action: Potassium channel blocker
  • Ocular complications include:
    • Keratopathy
    • Anterior subcapsular cataract
    • Optic neuropathy
    • Pigmentary retinopathy
    • Pseudotumor cerebri

 

Other important adverse effects:

 

  • Blue/grey skin deposits
  • Hypo/hyperthyroidism
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Bradycardia
  • Hepatotoxic
  • Constipation

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior Polar Cataract is located at the posterior pole of the lens and is often due to congenital posterior capsular dehiscence. It has a whirl like appearance.


 

Option C. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC) forms under the posterior capsule of the lens. This type of cataract is associated with several factors, including long-term use of corticosteroids, radiation, and intraocular inflammation.

 

It has a “bread crump” appearance

 

 

Option D. Anterior Polar Cataract forms at the front pole of the lens and is often congenital. It's not typically associated with medication use like Amiodarone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with anterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page 367

questions.text: Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Krukenberg Spindle

 

Option D:

 

  • Pigment dispersion syndrome & Pigmentary glaucoma are characterized by the liberation of pigment granules from iris pigment epithelium, and their deposition throughout the anterior segment.
  • In this, pigment is deposited on the endothelium in a vertical spindle shape.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudo-Exfoliation: The anterior lens capsule commonly exhibits a central disc with a peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material that shows radial indentations. These two components are separated by a clear zone, which is maintained through abrasion caused by the movement of the pupil.

 

 

Option B. Sampaolesi Line: Refers to pigment deposits that can be observed on or anterior to the Schwalbe's line, particularly in heavily pigmented angles like seen in Pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Glaukomflecken: Refers to small, focal areas of anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities that develop within the pupillary area. These opacities are considered pathognomonic of previous episodes of acute congestive angle closure and represent focal infarcts of the lens epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deposition of pigments on the endothelium of cornea in a spindle shaped central vertical orientation is called Krukenberg Spindle.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 368 & 370

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

 

Option D.

 

  • The picture shows right homonymous hemianopia.

  • Site of lesion – left optic tract.

  • This is associated with Wernicke’s pupil.

 

 

 

Wernicke Pupil

 

When the optic chiasm is bisected sagittally, the nasal halves of each retina become insensitive to light so that there is not only a bitemporal hemianopia but also a bitemporal pupillary hemiakinesia; that is, light falling on the nasal retina of either eye will fail to produce a pupillary constriction. Thus, if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation. It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil, it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil. It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.

 

Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction. It is detected using the swinging flashlight test. However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of right homonymous hemianopia, the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract, and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 312

2. Walsh and Hoyt’s Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology 6th Edition pg. No: 747
